BARRING OF BARN ROAD TO MOTORISTS
Ever increasing traffic problems
on the campus have been confronting university officials for the past
several years. Of late, however,
due to the growing number of automobiles operated by students and
members of the faculty, it has been
definitely proved that immediate
steps must be taken to procure a
remedy for the daily congestion and
the danger incurred by pedestrians.
Consequently, a new road is rapidly nearing completion, leading
from the lower Charles Street entrance to the University grounds
along the south side of the Civil Engineering and,Mechanical Engineering Buildings, and then joining the
old road running along the west
side of the Civil Engineering

present spaces on the south of Gilman Hall.
Measures are alai being discussed
by Dean Ames and Dr. Goodnow
to substitute a convenient entrance
to the University instead of the
short cut across the bowl, now being used by the students. This
daily practice is wearing a path
across the bowl, which is one of the
most attractive spots in the University grounds.

The remedy, at present being debated, entails the erection of two
hedges, one along the bottom and
the other around the top of the
bowl. Sidewalks will then be laid
along the side of the road around
the circle, connecting by a direct
route with the steps on the east side
of
the Chemical Laboratory.

FOUR NEW COLLEGES
ON TRACK SCHEDULE
Gettysburg, Richmond, Washington and Randolph-Macon
Newcomers
TWO MEETS AT HOMEWOOD
University of Maryland to Be
Met at College Park
Six dual meets and the Penn Relays constitute the schedule of the
Blue Jay track team for the coming
season. A large percentage of our
meets are out-of-town this spring,
five meets being away, and only
two on the Homewood cinderpath.
Gettysburg Meet First

Gettysburg College will initiate
the track program with a dual meet
held at Homewood Field on Saturday, April 9. In the two successive
weeks there are two out-of-town
meets, namely, University of Richmond, and Swarthmore College.
The week following the meet at
Swarthmore will be filled by the
Penn Relays, held on April 30. Our
old rival, University of Maryland,
will be met at College Park on May
7. The next meet is the only other
one to be staged at Homewood, and
will be with Washington College.
Randolph-Macon Closes

A meet with Randolph-Macon at
Ashland, Va., will conclude the season. This meet has not been finally closed," Manager Miles stated,
"but everything except the guarantee has been practically settled."
Team Should Be Strong

Captain Gwinn, Vivell, McNeal,
Pindell, Scheibel, Scheidt, Hemmeter, and Hershey should form the
nucleus of a successful team. Gwinn
and Scheibel have shown their heels
to most of the cross-country runners of the state during the fall.
Gwinn, it will be remembered, lowerned Verne Booth's record for the
mile and approached Booth's mark
in the two-mile, the latter's specialty.
The team will be strengthened
considerably by Paul Zepp, former
Poly runner, who is now a member
of the freshman class. Zepp runs
the quarter and half mile runs.
Three veterans are back to take
care of field events. Tom McNeal,

year's veterans, have been making
excellent times in the 440.
The fancy diving is giving Hill
little worry since Captain Stone and
Hemmeter, regular divers last year,
will represent the Jays again this
season.
Provided that Lee is used in the
breast stroke, Hopkins should be
sure of either first or second in that
event in all meets. And with Smith
and Brack improving daily, this
sems to be one of the strongest
departments of the team.
Hopkins' swimming teams have
always been weak in the back stroke
but this season Hill is hopeful of developing a good swimmer in this
race. Boyce and Muir, members of
last season's team, the former the
present Hopkins record holders, are
both available again this year, while
Hiss, Stone and Chapman, all new
candidates for this event, have been
progressing nicely.
Practice will be held this Thursday and then discontinued until
after the examinations when, according to Hill, serious -work will
be renewed and a tentative team se.
lected for the opening meet with
Army on February 19.

arms extended full length, chin
touching the water. Then kick up
and down from the hips, legs alternating. The whole secret of the
flutter kick is to relax the legs absolutely. Do not kick too hard or too
often and do not open the legs too
wide, as you lose the power of the
leg drive. Leave the legs as loose
as possible, then try to shake your
ankles off your feet. In this operation the legs should not open more
than ten to twelve inches and
should be loose at the hips and
knees.
SECTION 5-Breathing.
Breathing for the crawl stroke is
more or less an individual study
after the first principles have been
mastered. Your head should turn
slightly more than the roll when
you want to take a breath. As the
arm and shoulder is brought to the

by another quick but short sweep

by nose while face is under water,
just before you come back to the
first breathing position for another
deep breath.
SECTION 6 Turning in Pool
With Crawl Stroke.
The easiest way to get a fast turn
is to turn in the direction opposite
to the side used in breathing. For
instance, if you breathe on the left
side, or as the right arm reaches
forward, it will be to your advantage to turn to the right. If
breathing on the right side, turn to
the left. In turning to the right,
for example, when within one foot
of the wall, with the right arm extended, instead of pulling downward as usual with the right arm,
sweep it horizontally to the left; as
the left arm touches the wall with

definitely proved that immediate
steps must be taken to procure a
remedy for the daily congestion and
the danger incurred by pedestrians.
Consequently, a new road is rapidly nearing completion, leading
from the lower Charles Street entrance to the University grounds
along the south side of the Civil Engineering and,Mechanical Engineering Buildings, and then joining the
old road running along the west
side of the Civil Engineering

FOUR NEW COLLEGES
ON TRACK SCHEDULE
Gettysburg, Richmond, Washington and Randolph-Macon
Newcomers
TWO MEETS AT HOMEWOOD
University of Maryland to Be
Met at College Park
Six dual meets and the Penn Relays constitute the schedule of the
Blue Jay track team for the coming
season. A large percentage of our
meets are out-of-town this spring,
five meets being away, and only
two on the Homewood cinderpath.
Gettysburg Meet First

Gettysburg College will initiate
the track program with a dual meet
held at Homewood Field on Saturday, April 9. In the two successive
weeks there are two out-of-town
meets, namely, University of Richmond, and Swarthmore College.
The week following the meet at
Swarthmore will be filled by the
Penn Relays, held on April 30. Our
old rival, University of Maryland,
will be met at College Park on May
7. The next meet is the only other
one to be staged at Homewood, and
will be with Washington College.
Randolph-Macon Closes

A meet with Randolph-Macon at
Ashland, Va., will conclude the season. This meet has not been finally closed," Manager Miles stated,
"but everything except the guarantee has been practically settled."
Team Should Be Strong

Captain Gwinn, Vivell, McNeal,
Pindell, Scheibel, Scheidt, Hemmeter, and Hershey should form the
nucleus of a successful team. Gwinn
and Scheibel have shown their heels
to most of the cross-country runners of the state during the fall.
Gwinn, it will be remembered, lowerned Verne Booth's record for the
mile and approached Booth's mark
in the two-mile, the latter's specialty.
The team will be strengthened
considerably by Paul Zepp, former
Poly runner, who is now a member
of the freshman class. Zepp runs
the quarter and half mile runs.
Three veterans are back to take

year's veterans, have been making

The fancy diving is giving Hill
little worry since Captain Stone and
Hemmeter, regular divers last year,
will represent the Jays again this
season.
Provided that Lee is used in the
breast stroke, Hopkins should be
sure of either first or second in that
event in all meets. And with Smith
and Brack improving daily, this
sems to be one of the strongest
departments of the team.
Hopkins' swimming teams have
always been weak in the back stroke
but this season Hill is hopeful of developing a good swimmer in this
race. Boyce and Muir, members of
last season's team, the former the
present Hopkins record holders, are
both available again this year, while
Hiss, Stone and Chapman, all new
candidates for this event, have been
progressing nicely.
Practice will be held this Thursday and then discontinued until
after the examinations when, according to Hill, serious -work will
be renewed and a tentative team se.
lected for the opening meet with

arms extended full length, chin
touching the water. Then kick up
and down from the hips, legs alternating. The whole secret of the
flutter kick is to relax the legs absolutely. Do not kick too hard or too
often and do not open the legs too
wide, as you lose the power of the
leg drive. Leave the legs as loose
as possible, then try to shake your
ankles off your feet. In this operation the legs should not open more
than ten to twelve inches and
should be loose at the hips and
knees.
SECTION 5-Breathing.
Breathing for the crawl stroke is
more or less an individual study
after the first principles have been
mastered. Your head should turn
slightly more than the roll when
you want to take a breath. As the
arm and shoulder is brought to the

by another quick but short sweep

by nose while face is under water,
just before you come back to the
first breathing position for another
deep breath.
SECTION 6 Turning in Pool
With Crawl Stroke.
The easiest way to get a fast turn
is to turn in the direction opposite
to the side used in breathing. For
instance, if you breathe on the left
side, or as the right arm reaches
forward, it will be to your advantage to turn to the right. If
breathing on the right side, turn to
the left. In turning to the right,
for example, when within one foot
of the wall, with the right arm extended, instead of pulling downward as usual with the right arm,
sweep it horizontally to the left; as
the left arm touches the wall with
palm of hand, fingers pointed downward and the knees being well
drawn up.

chairman, Robert L. Bull, Eugene
O'Dunne, and E. R. Fenimore, alternate. Members of the junior team
were: J. Carey Thompson, chairman, Irvin 13. Hoffman, Norman B.
Gardiner, and Joseph Watkins, alternate.
